title: WBS Pens set for 1st preseason game of season
text:
WBS Pens set for 1st preseason game of season By Seth Lakso, Staff Writer Published: September 30, 2015 Sign Up Text Alerts | newsletter 
WILKES-BARRE — Of the 22 players at the Wilkes-Barre/Scranton Penguins training camp, maybe five can say with any kind of confidence they know they’re going to start the season here. 
For the other 17 or so, tonight’s preseason game against Lehigh Valley at Mohegan Sun Arena is a make-or-break moment. 
With the Pittsburgh Penguins — whose roster sits at 49 — closing out a set of three preseason games in three days tonight, it’s expected that close to 20 players will be hitting the waiver wire or heading toward Wilkes-Barre/Scranton. 
Penguins general manager Jim Rutherford said Monday he’d like to have his team all but set for the team’s final preseason game Friday at Carolina. 
As a result, a lot of the faces now in Wilkes-Barre/Scranton will either be in search of a job, or heading for Wheeling on Friday. 
With that in mind, WBS Penguins coach Mike Sullivan huddled his guys together at the close of Tuesday’s practice at the Toyota SportsPlex and shared a message. 
“I just told the guys on the ice that (the preseason game is) an opportunity to make an impression and that you don’t know how many of those opportunities that you’re going to get sometimes,” Sullivan said. “So, when (they) present themselves, you have to be prepared to take advantage and maximize that. 
“For some of these guys, this may be their only opportunity. So they certainly want to make the most of that and make an impression on everyone involved.” 
Added pressure or not, Sullivan said the team is looking forward to hitting the ice tonight. 
“We’re excited to play an opponent other than ourselves,” he said. “I think we’ve had four hard days here. Productive days. 
“Now, it’s an opportunity for everyone to show what they can do. I think it will be great feedback for the coaches as far as what we’re trying to implement from a systems standpoint, whether or not we’re having success.” 
Napkin talk 
Here’s a look at the lines for tonight’s game: 
Forwards: Tom Kostopoulos-Sahir Gill-Ty Loney; Riley Brace-Jarrett Burton-Adam Krause; Cody Wydo-Christophe Lalancette-Derek Army and Pat McGrath-Shane Bakker-John McCarron 
Defensemen: Mathew Malone-Harris Ruopp; Nick Petrecki-Ryan Parent and Brett Stern-Clark Seymour 
Goaltenders: Brian Foster and Casey DeSmith 
Not playing: Carter Rowney, Paul Cianfrini and Michael Beauregard 
Rowney has been battling an undisclosed injury, so his absence is likely precautionary. 
Foster is expected to play the first two periods, with DeSmith taking over for the third. 
Loney, who is skating on the top line with Gill and Kostopoulos, will be someone to keep an eye on. He is the son of former NHL player, Troy Loney, who won two Stanley Cups with the Penguins. 
The 23-year old signed with the Penguins organization after playing four seasons at the University of Denver, where he totaled 39 goals, 50 assists and 128 penalty minutes in 152 games. 
Loney, who is one of eight players in Wilkes-Barre/Scranton on an AHL contract, made his professional debut last year when he signed with the Norfolk Admirals and recorded a goal and two assists in his professional debut on April 7 at Binghamton. 
He finished with four points (2G-2A) in five appearances for the Admirals.
